text:
We used this recipe for rolled out cookies. I baked them for 11 minute- I took them out before they started to brown,as we wanted super soft cookies. They came out great. The dough held its shape well, and didnt require chilling before rolling and cutting. I found it very easy to work with.  I sprinkled one pan with cinnamon and sugar before baking- they were great! The kids used frosting on some of them. Since they are not super sweet on their own, the frosting isnt to much. edit to add: we've made this recipe a few times now. Its even better if you add the zest of one medium orange. It gives them a bit more flavor.

text:
Absolutely wonderful!  Be sure to cream the butter, shortening, and sugar together until mixture is light and fluffy before proceding to next step.  This will make a big difference.  Also, it helps to chill the dough before rolling into balls.  This is the best sugar cookie I've ever tasted!  It's a keeper!

text:
I enjoyed this recipe. There was nothing really spectacular about the flavor. It tasted like a normal sugar cookie. The texture however, was fantastic. It yielded nice soft cookies than browned perfectly in 10 minutes. The sugar on the outside gave a crunchy coating that contrasted beautifully with the soft centers. I also enjoyed how easy this recipe was to make. I didn't have any shortening on hand, so I just used butter, but they still came out very nice.

text:
I just made these and, after reading all of the reviews, I should give my input as well... I gave these only 4 stars because of misleading directions. The recipe implies that these cookies will spread to give the classic sugar cookie shape. This is completely untrue. If you roll them as written an place them on your cookie sheet, that's exactly what you will get when you take them out ten minutes later - a great tasting cookie ball. If you use your fingers to press them down, you'll end up with nice little impressions of your fingers. The taste and texture ARE fantastic (I followed exactly as written - except for not rolling in sugar since I plan on frosting mine) BUT you must dip the bottom of a glass in some fine sugar and then use this to press down your cookies. That's the only way to get the desired shape. Any imperfections when going into the oven will be seen when the cookies come out, so if you don't like ragged edges on your cookie - reshape with your hand while on the cookie sheet before going into the oven. And, yes, I did these large and small size - still needed to be pressed down and shaped by hand for looks. Definitely try this recipe for a wonderful taste and texture, but know that the directions are leading you astray when it comes to how to get the desired cookie...

text:
I usually use less salt than recipes call for and after reading a review that said less salt might be better, I opted to use 1/2 tsp rather than the recipes's called for 1 tsp. The only other change I made was using about 3 cups flour rather than 3 1/2 cups.  Reason for this was my hand blender started smelling like the motor was burning out when I got to 3 cups, so I turned it off-finished blending the batter by hand.  I baked 10 min at 350, the bottoms were golden the top part of cookie still very pale.  Finished by topping with a butter-powder sugar frosting. For quality assurance, I promptly ate 5 in a row to make sure my review was accurate.  These cookies need one more thing not mentioned in the recipe:  a large glass of cold milk.  Bringing in a dozen of these to my fav co-worker today so I don't eat them all.  Really good cookies.  Fluffy light soft. Nice.
UPDATE:  Test drove this recipe replacing the shortening with organic coconut oil with good results. Expensive, but flavorful and healthy. To anyone wondering, yes, you can replace shortening with coconut oil, organic or refined. I make these cookies almost weekly now. Any version of recipe is good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these cookies for my family at Christmas for the last few years.  I thought it was time to post some tips for those who may have encountered problems with this recipe.

You can scale this recipe up to 36 servings to avoid the odd measurements of butter and shortening.  Or, you can scale it down to as little as 12 servings.

I always chill the dough for 1 hour before baking.  Any longer than that and the dough will get too cold, too hard, and the cookies will be raw in the middle (The tops/centers should look pale and white).  If the centers look wet or grey, they're underdone.

After rolling the balls of dough into an additional amount of sugar, you must flatten them (to an even thickness) using the bottom of a 1/4 or 1/8 cup measuring cup.  If you don't, they will not bake all the way through in the center.

If your dough is closer to room temperature, bake the cookies for 8:45.  If the dough is colder and firmer, bake for 10 minutes.

If the dough cracks or crumbles when you try rolling it into balls, it is a sign that the dough may be slightly dry.  To offset this, add a tiny amount of milk, water, or canola oil to your hands and pat the dough softly until it seems fully moistened (and does not crack or crumble when rolling it into balls).

On the flip side, if the dough seems too sticky or wet after mixing, add enough flour to keep it from sticking to your hands before refrigerating.

I hope this helps.

text:
I am not a huge sugar cookie fan, but these blew my socks off! And my husband and daughter both loved them. They are indeed soft in the middle and delightfully crunchy on the outside when baked correctly, and the taste is just what one expects from a sugar cookie.  I don't really consider it a deviation from the recipe, but I used butter-flavored shortening. Otherwise I left all the ingredients the same.  The recipe instructions didn't call for it, but I did chill my dough overnight before rolling and baking. This was a great help in handling the dough, and it doesn't seem to have hurt the cookies at all.  I rolled mine in a mixture of "Raw Sugar" and colored sugars. The cookies were attractive and delicious at the same time.  This recipe will remain in my recipe box; it's rare that I find a sugar cookie I actually like. Next year I may try icing!

text:
This is a 10 star recipe!  I have made these many ways, rolled and cut, thick, thin, and I always make them as written first.  To top them I have used sugar, canned frosting and hard icing.  They stay soft for days no matter how you store them.  When I ice them they have to stay out to harden the icing and they are still soft even after 4 or 5 days!  Just do not rolls them too thin and do not refigerate the dough overnight.  It is a very soft dough but rolls easily.  Refigerate for maybe 1/2 hr. if the dough is too soft.  I have also found that I like the larger cookies better than the small ones (probably because they taste so good!)  =)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/232330.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are so easy to make and is very forgiving! I did not have enough shortening but after reading several reviews, I went ahead and made them with all butter. They still turned out light and soft. I am not a huge sugar cookie fan but my family likes them. After mixing the dough, I decided I would like it a little sweeter. I added about 1/4 cup more sugar. This is my personal taste and does not mean the recipe as stated is off. I just don't like icing so prefer to up the sugar in the dough to compensate.  I rolled into balls dipped in colored sugar and then flattened with a glass. My oven runs a little hot so I cooked them 9 minutes, cooled on pan one minute and then moved to cooling rack. Perfect.

text:
Excellent sugar cookies!  Very buttery tasting and very soft. Not flavorless like the ones you buy in the grocery store bakery, but just as soft and light.  I also like that it doesn't call for any ingredients I may not have on hand all the time like sour cream or cream of tarter.

Just FYI:  I wanted a recipe to make cut-outs, but I found this dough a bit mushy for that, even after chilling a while.  so if you want to make cut out cookies for decorating instead of rolled in sugar as in the recipe, I'd add an additional cup of flour.  Even with that flour, these cookies were soft and very tasty and turned out perfect as Valentines hearts.

text:
As my great-grandmother used to say, sugar cookies bring out the best flavors of tea by not competing with it!  So, don't expect this recipe to produce a highly-flavored cookie.  Instead, enjoy them with tea. :)  While my G-G'ma made the traditional crispy sugar cookie, I tried this recipe because my husband prefers soft cookies.  I tried patting out the dough and using cutters (my 2.5 year old was helping), but it wasn't firm enough -- next time I'll try refrigerating the dough for a while.  Even as drop cookies, these are enjoyable and oh so soft!  I bet they'll be perfect with tea!

These are great!  Followed the recipe exactly.  I rolled these out and made them into the traditional circles.  I did not refrigerate and I had NO issue at all rolling them out. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies were soft! I kinda wanted my cookies to turn out like the picture. Some said the cookies don't expand. But my did which was why I was kinda disappointed they came out a little flat. THe first time I made the cookies I used butter instead of shortening. And they spread alot and the dough was sticky bad for cut out cookies but came out soft though. The second time I used  vegetable oil to substitute shortening and the dough was less watery and I think I had it in the refrigerator at least an hour or so could be used for cut out cookies. I had no trouble rolling the second batch into a ball using my hands. but the first batch man I needed alot of flower. The first batch was salty and kinda sweet it was like first taste was sweet then came the salt. And could have been from the butter. So the second time I didn't add salt and add an extra teaspoon of vanilla. Was sweet maybe kinda too sweet but in a way expected taste from a sugar cookie. I dont know if I should buy a tub of shortening for this recipe. But hands down you want a soft cookie this is it.

text:
These cookies are absolutely wonderful! I am eating one now as I write this review, almost one week later. They keep so well, but I have also been using the bread trick (tear off a piece of bread and stick in your cookie container and it will keep them soft). This was my first attempt ever at sugar cookies and this dough is perfect for rolling out if you do so at about 1/2" thick. I roll my dough between 2 pieces of saran wrap which makes it so much easier and less messy. I also used the Sugar Cookie Icing by JBS BOX on this site and it was the perfect complement. My pet peeve is hard sugar cookies and these are so unbelievably soft! This is my go-to recipe for sure!!

userID:
624881
Display Name:
ANGELSTAR
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
92
favoritesCount:
455
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/98611.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been looking for a good sugar cookie recipe that's soft like my sisters who uses a 16oz bag of powdered sugar. This one hit the spot! Before I rolled them out I chilled them for a few hours to make them easier to roll and shape. I didn't put them in a ball and smush them like they say. They held their form very easily and were very easy to work with on a heavily floured surface, they didn't fall apart when I put them on the pan. I rolled them out to half of a centimeter or a little less.  They baked for 9 minutes, once you can see the tan on the edges, they're already overcooked. I used "Sugar Cookie Icing" by JBS Box. They came out like store bought sugar cookies, except better! Delectable!

text:
These didn't turn out well for me. I did as I read a couple other people did, which was using all butter rather than half shortening. Maybe that made a larger difference than I thought it would, because these turned out really like a flour-butter mixture. The first couple of cookies I forgot to flatten out, and they turned out slightly doughy in the center, which would have been ok but the flavor seemed sort of off. The rest I flattened, but didn't do much for the texture. My husband loves sugar cookies but didn't like these. Sorry, but I won't be making these again.

text:
This is a wonderful basic recipe -- you can be creative and add your own touches.  The cookies come out dense, kindav a cross between a sugar cookie and a shortbread cookie.  I added 1/2 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar, as some other reviewers suggested.  I made these for a Halloween party and decorated them with colored sugar, frosting, and icing.  It was amazing how quickly they disappeared!  I didn't even get a chance to try one.  I had people coming up to me all night telling me they loved the cookies.  Thanks so much for the recipe!  It's a keeper!

text:
I have made these four or five times and people absolutely love them.  I leave the sugar off the top and then ice them with a butter cream frosting. This is not a sugar cookie I would serve plain-it needs some kind of frosting on it.  I scoop them out with a cookie scoop, flatten them with a milk glass dipped in flour and then bake for 10 minutes at 350 degrees.  This simple cookie was by far the most popular item at our Thanksgiving dinner this year.

None
text:
love love love this recipe! they come out soft and chewy, though i found that when you first take them out of the oven the middles appear soft. my mom thought they were too doughy so she had me make batch and flatten the balls out a little before baking. they didn't seem as doughy when first taking them out but after they cooled i found that the ones that i had pushed down turned crispy. The ones that i has just rolled as the recipe stated stayed nice and fluffy and my mom agreed that after fully cooling they didn't seem doughy. So my advice is to just do as the recipe says, roll them up and bake and you will have the worlds perfect sugar cookie! :)

text:
I made these last night and had to wait until now to review since I've tried some recipes that almost broke my teeth next morning, they were so hard....but not these!  They held their tasty softness. :-)  Of course, I made some minor adjustments to give extra softness and light buttery flavor, so for us, they're perfect! 
I added 3/4 cups more sugar; added an extra tsp vanilla; instead of straight shortening, only used 1/3 cup plus 2 sticks real butter (1cup), and 1/3 cup Country Crock tub spread.  You'll want to make sure you blend wet ingredients well BEFORE you add the eggs, then handle as little as possible afterward, for added softness.  After one bite, my husband fell in love all over again! ;-)  Enjoy!

text:
A great recipe! Super simple and very tasty.  I followed the recipe exactly and watched the video 10 times to be sure I was doing it right.  I only needed 11 minutes exactly to get them perfectly cooked in my oven.  I hand rolled them and pressed them into colored sugar flattening them just a little with my fingers before placing them on the cookie sheet, and they came just right.

I made another batch where I added two teaspoons of raspberry extract along with the vanilla extract and it just gave these cookies an extra oomph, I loved it even better than the orginal recipe.  My boss who is a Master baker tried them, and she loved the raspberry infused ones.  Next time I will add some real raspberry preserves to the middle.  I cannot wait to experiment with different extracts like peppermint, orange, and almond.  The skies the limit with these cookies as far as extracts and toppings.  Have fun.

These cookies were awesome!  So easy to make and had such great flavor!
I DO recommend pressing each ball of cookie dough down lightly before baking, as the cookies do not spread out very much.  I used the bottom of a glass for this.  Just don't flatten the dough too thin or you'll have thin and crispy "sugar crackers" instead of cookies, haha.

Made these for the 2nd time today and this time I used white whole wheat flour from King Aurthur.  AMAZING!!!  Didn't change the light and fluffy cookie at all. text:
I've made this as is, but prefer it with all butter. I also like icing on top as opposed to the additional sugar (look up the sugar cookie icing recipe on this site--and consider adding lemon or cinnamon to make them special). Since these are soft, they are like mall cookies when you put icing on them and this adds to the flavor since these are not very sweet. As is, though, they are quite good and go well with coffee or tea. I had one for breakfast this morning--not healthy but yummy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/507575.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are so simple to make and taste soooo good. The key to keep them from spreading is the shortening. I made these over and over with all butter becasue I didn't want to use shortening. And no matter how long they were in the fridge or freezer they would always spread. I gave in and tried it with the shortening and to my surprise, they held their shape. I added a little extra vanilla becasue I like the flavor and did not refridgerate it before baking. Rolled the dough into balls, rolled them in sugars, then used a cup to slightly flatten them. Baked perfect at 11 mins.

hope you all have better luck than we did.

text:
This recipe is awsome for cookie cutters also; In my oven; only 7mins to cook. I've made it 2x in the last 2months for the holidays. I've never made homemade sugar cookies with cut outs. Always thought it was a lot of work, but this recipe is easy. The dough does at first look too dry to roll out but work it into a ball and your hands warm up the dough and it rolls nice. I have a wooden rolling pin and the dough did just fine with adding flour to my rolling pin. Do not make dough too thin. I'm no pro when it comes to dough. I totally recommend this recipe to anyone who wants to give it a try. Have the kids help cut out the cookies. The recipe gives me about 4 dozen, so it can take up some time if your new to cookie cutting dough. Have fun.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'd never made sugar cookies like this before- Only the kind you roll out and cut into shapes. However, my boyfriend wanted some regular old sugar cookies, so I found this recipe. This was a very simple recipe to follow and the dough was super-easy to work with.   I'm not a huge fan of sugar cookies, so I thought they tasted ok, but everyone else who tried them really liked them.   The only problem I had was that when I rolled them and put them directly on the baking sheet, they came out all round and puffy and looking like little turtle shells (which would be really cute if you tinted the dough green), so I started scrunching them after rolling them in the sugar. I kind of expected I'd need to scrunch them, but I wasn't sure if the dough would spread out much, and it really doesn't, which is nice.   I baked them for about 10 minutes and they came out perfectly, although they were a little crunchier than I expected. Although they were pretty crunchy on the outside, they were still soft in the middle.   I suspect this recipe might also be good for cut-out sugar cookies as well.   Very good recipe :)

text:
THESE ARE MY NEW "ROLLED" SUGAR COOKIES!!! No more refrigerating for hours or back-breaking work rolling out dough for me! This is what i did: When i mixed up the  dough it was crumbly so i added apple sauce until the dough was moistened just enough(but not enough to be wet or sticky). Then all i had to do was pat out handfuls of the dough to my desired thickness directly onto a foil-lined baking sheet, cut out my shape, and peel the excess dough away! I made candy canes, stars, and christmas trees! They puffed up nicely but kept their shape! "Sugar Cookie Icing" gave them a glossy, professional finish perfect for my holiday cookie gift baskets!!

country:
None
text:
All I have to say is WOW!  This is exactly what I was looking for in a sugar cookie.  Another reviewer had said these reminded her of Lofthouse cookies.  She was right!  I had to do two substitutions due to a lack of ingredients on hand, but the result was so great I think I will use my modified version from now on.  Thanks so much for this recipe.  This definitely satisfied my sugar craving. =)

Substitutions:

1.  I used cake flour instead of all-purpose flour.  This yielded a more tender-crumbed cookie. (1 CUP all-purpose flour = 1 CUP + 2 TBSPS cake flour)

2. I used all butter instead of butter and shortening as called for in the recipe.  

Tips:
1. Know your oven - mine runs a little on the hot side so I baked my cookies for only about 9 minutes, turned off the oven, and let them sit in there for about 2 minutes before pulling them out.

2. After mixing, I placed the bowl in the fridge for approximately 5 minutes to chill slightly.  I find working with cooler dough to be easier and less messy.

3. DO NOT OVER BAKE...unless you like crunchy cookies.  This can never be stressed enough.

text:
I have a gentleman friend that craves soft cookies! I wanted to treat him after a stressful day. I found these and the reviews raved...and they have never let me down! These are awesome! Soft, but not heavy in any way. I also used real butter with the butter flavored shortening. The sweet and buttery flavor was amazing. If food is the way to a mans heart...these cookies will keep him around a long time. The recipe I have used from my mother for the past 20 years hit the shredder. Sorry Mom :)

Follow-up guilty admission! I was having one of those days that nothing seems to go right. I wanted to splurge on my favorite "make me feel good treats", so I combined them! I made this recipe, (turned out great again)and let cool. In the mean time, I coarsely chopped Pecans and melted a bag of caramels. I dipped the tops of the cooled cookies into the caramel, pressed them into the chopped pecans, and when the caramel was cool, melted a bag of chocolate chips and once the melted chocolate started to cool, spread it all over the top of the cookies. Probably not the first one to think of it...but after a couple, all was well in the world of gayle again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good, easy recipe. The edges are getting a little crisp (about 30 min out of the oven) but the middles are still soft.  The edges get cracked when flattening with a glass, which I did in order to prevent coming out with ball-shaped cookies.  I used all butter instead of part shortening and part butter (to avoid trans-fats).  I also experimented with using a small cookie cutter on a little of the dough to see how these would hold their shape if I wanted to use this recipe for cut-outs; the dough was a little hard to handle when transferring the shaped dough to the sheet for baking (such soft dough) and the cut-outs did puff up a little bit. They'd be fine as simple shapes (hearts, etc.) but not for more ornate cookies (snowflakes, etc.).  Overall, these fulfilled my husband's craving for a soft sugar cookie.

text:
These are very delicious.  I love that you don't have to roll them out.  They are especially good with frosting.  The baking time needs to be closely monitored because I found that if they were even slightly overbaked, they weren't soft and chewy.  Also, they seemed to loose the softnes once they were frozen.  They taste their best when they are fresh.  All in all however, a great recipe for sugar cookies.

text:
Wonderful! Per other reviewers' comments, I decreased salt to 1/2 teaspoon. I did not roll mine in granulated sugar, and they were still sweet enough to enjoy on their own. Adding icing, though, brings these into heavenly territory! You may want to flatten the tops a bit before putting the balls of dough into the oven. I did this with all my pans after the first one, as I felt they came out a little too high when I didn't smush the balls down a little first. These taste like an even better version of the Lofthouse ones, without all the preservatives, etc.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to bake Christmas cookies with my boys and needed a recipe that was good for rolling and cutting.  I also wanted cookies that were soft.  So, as someone who had never baked cookies before, this recipe was perfect!  I actually baked as written and also rolled some dough out for cutting, and both methods worked well.  If you want to roll out the dough, try wrapping the dough in some wax paper and putting in the fridge for about 30 min to an hour.  Then roll out between two pieces of wax paper.  Dip cookie cutters in cold water just prior to cutting.  Also, I added about 1/4 tsp of almond essence for extra flavor.  Yum Yum Yum!!!.

I very rarely eat sweets as I don't like very sweet things, but there is just something about the Lofthouse cookies that I can't resist. I have been known to eat 1/2 the package before reaching the registers! These are better. Holy Toledo, make these cookies! Per other reviews, substituted 1 tsp of the vanilla with almond, cookie scooped onto pan, pushed down about halfway with colored sugar dipped glass bottom. Baked 10 minutes, removed to rack after about a minute so they would not continue cooking or dry out on hot sheet pan. Perfect! I'm using pastel sugar and taking to a baby shower and then doing again for Easter because they're so pretty as well as yummy :)

text:
This is a quick and really yummy recipe... I did run out of vanilla extract and did not quite have enough for this recipe so i substituted a little bit of sugar free vanilla syrup (the kind used for snow cones) and these still came out delicious and also added a little extra flavor. Some of the reviews I read said these were a little plain in the flavor dept. I'm not sure if it was the syrup I used but these were sooo good...and full of flavor...I am going to get some more vanilla and stick to the recipe next time but we wanted some cookies tonight and I didn't feel like getting out just for vanilla....

text:
FOLLOWED RECIPE EXACTLY AND THEY WERE AMAZING!  I did as others stated and refrigerated dough for about 30 mins to keep it from being sticky.  (Although I don't think it was that bad without refrigerating.)  I used a melon baller to measure out a heaping scoop of each cookie.  Made them into balls, placed on cookie sheet, and then pressed down slightly with bottom of glass to flatten a little.  I kept mine about 1/8 - 1/4 inch thick. So chewy! Excellent flavor!  I WILL DEFINITELY MAKE THESE AGAIN!

i really like this sugar cookie recipe. I would suggest using just a little less salt. when tasting the dough ( you know we all do it)...I really tasted more salt then I like. After they were baked..I thought...they were just a little too salty but a really soft cookie. All I had to do to fix it is to reduce the salt! I would recommend just using 3/4 or 1/2 teaspoon of salt! Mind as well..it would be better for you.

country:
None
text:
Made these over the weekend.  Dough was quite sticky and definitely not "rollable".  Had to add quite a bit extra flour to get them to roll into balls, but didn't hurt them one bit.  
Subbed almond extract for the vanilla, didn't roll in sugar before baking & took them out of the oven just as they started looking like they were getting color on the bottom edges. Came out excellent.  Great flavor, great texture, definitely sweet enough for my tastes without any icing added & still soft today.  Thinking I may try a citrus version with some with lemon extract and grated orange & lime rind added.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The dough came out excellent.  I ran out of shortening so I had to use 1 cup butter and 1/3 cup shortening, but it didn't seem to make much of a difference.  I wanted to make a seasonal cookie, so I took 1/4 of the dough, mixed in about 1/3 cup pumpkin butter, a dash of cinnamon, a dash of nutmeg, and about a cup of flour to bring the consistency back.  I then rolled out the plain dough into a long rectangle, spread the pumpkin dough on top, and rolled it into a cylinder.  I wrapped the dough in plastic wrap, put it the fridge for a few hours, and then sliced and baked.  It came out with a nice subtle flavor, perfectly done at 10 minutes.  I think next time I'll roll them in a cinnamon sugar mix to give a little extra spice.

text:
These were good with a few modifications.  I like my sugar cookies a little flatter so I pressed them with a glass before baking (they don't spread or flatten at all on their own). I also used a medium cookie scoop to speed the rolling/balling process and keep them uniform size.  I baked mine for 12 minutes and they great.  I tried baking longer but they got too crispy and lost their flavor.  I brought them to work and people said, "They taste just like the ones from the store!"  I guess that's a good thing?

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3969188.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A most excellent sugar cookie!  They were soft and chewy, even a little fluffy!  I rolled them into golfball sized balls, but they keep their shape so well that I think I'll be using cookie cutters next time.   The only thing I would change about this recipe would be to add only 1/2 tsp salt instead of a full tsp.  They were just a little salty for my taste.  Also, this is a mildly flavored cookie, so a basic confectioners sugar/vanilla extract glaze, frosting, or other goodies (choc. chips, almond extract, etc.) make a perfect addition.  Yum!

I was really skeptical when I started mixing these up because the batter wasn't as sweet as normal sugar cookie. When they were done (10 min was perfect), boy was I pleasantly suprised!  I did only add 1/2 tsp salt because 1 tsp seemed too much and I used a T cookie scoop instead of rolling them.  They were pretty small and would make them bigger the next time and just pat them down a little to make a wider cookie.  I frosted with the sugar cookie frosting recipe on the site and they were great!  These have a excellent texture and when they're done, they'll be gone quick!

I signed up for an All Recipes membership just so that I could tell all of you that you MUST make these sugar cookies!  They are easy because you don't have to refrigerate the dough or roll it out. What makes them the best cookie is the texture. Soft and chewy and they stay that way as long as you keep them covered. There are only a couple small things I tweaked just to add more flavor. 1.  I used Butter flavored shortening for more butter flavor 2.  I put the zest of one lemon in with the wet ingredients 3.  Instead of rolling in sugar, I put a cream cheese frosting on them when cooled completely.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/670599.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love the way this sugar cookie turned out for me. I think these are definitely my new favourite. The reason I decided to try this recipe was because it had no milk listed in the ingredients. I didn't roll my dough in sugar before baking, but instead frosted it with Butter Icing for Cookies (recipe also from this site) It was the prefect combination as the cookie itself is not too sweet. I stored my cookies in an airtight container in the fridge and they had a lovely soft yet chewy texture to them. Also cause I only wanted a few cookies I had cut down the recipe and still took a container and put some dough into it and stuck it in the freezer. The dough only remained in the freezer for the couple of days cause these cookies were so wonderful I just had to have more. I took my container with the dough out of the fridge to thaw and it thawed out quickly mind you. I just scooped the dough from the container and made it into balls and lightly pressed them down a little. My cookies still turned out perfectly round and still had the same texture as when I made the dough fresh. Wonderful sugar cookie recipe, when you don't have milk on hand!

text:
Yummy! I altered the recipe slightly since I'm in high altitude...Increased flour by 3 1/2 Tbl., decreased sugar to 1 1/3 C., decreased baking powder by 1/4 tsp. I also used butter flavored shortening instead of shortening and butter. Dipped bottom of a drinking glass in water and then sugar and pressed the balls, no need to dip into water after first time, the oils from the dough will make the sugar stick with each dip. Baked for 10 mintues and let sit for about a minute and a half on the sheet out of the oven. Perfect!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for my kids for a Valentine's Day after-school snack, and they are wonderful! I used all butter vs. shortening (I'm not a fan of that "shortening" taste) and didn't bother with rolling them in sugar, but I did flatten them slightly before baking. I found the dough very easy to work with, and only baked mine for about 9 minutes, then removed from the oven and let them sit on the hot cookie sheet for about 3 to finish doing their thing. This made for a perfectly soft/chewy center with a slightly crisp outside.  Once cooled, we frosted them with a basic buttercream icing (just find a good basic butter/powdered sugar/milk/vanilla recipe..takes 3 seconds to whip up!), and they were gone in no time! For those of you who found these to be bland, sugar cookies, in our experience, aren't necessarily supposed to be bursting with flavor by themselves...it's what you put on top of them that really brings out the yummy, buttery flavor of cookie! Thanks so much for this recipe - we've been looking for a SOFT sugar cookie recipe that doesn't have to be rolled out for a while now, and this one is just perfection!

text:
Ok, I know these are supposed to be soft but I prefer a crispier cookie.  So instead of 2/3c butter and 2/3c shortening I used 1/3c + 1/2c shortening and 1/2c butter.  I kept everything else the same and I have to say, these are some tasty cookies!  Perfect for my cookie press and everyone was so impressed with the results!  Thanks Laura!!!  ***UPDATE***  I decided to follow the recipe exactly for soft cookies.  I may like them crunchy but I really am all alone on that one and have had many requests for soft sugar cookies.  I came back to this recipe and it really delivered again.  Used my cookie scoop, rolled in sugar and flattened slightly with the bottom of glass.  The pic is of the soft version. Delicious.

text:
Oh yeah - these are wonderful!  We made these tonight to roll out and decorate, they came out great.  I was concerned that as roll outs the 10 minute cooking time would be too long however found out it was perfect.  The key to soft sugar cookies is definitely to not over bake them.  Great advice to fluff the flour while measuring, because my son was helping the 3 1/2 cups was slightly too much, I used another user's advice to press the dough together with wet hands and no problems.  Let the dough sit in the fridge for 2 hours and the dough worked well.  We loved them.

text:
Update:
I made this recipe again last night, also cutting it in half. It was much better this time. The changes I made were simple but great. I added a half tsp of nutmeg and doubled the vanilla. When you so not roll them in sugar but just press the balls to flatten and bake it makes a good Lofthouse-type soft/cake-y cookie.
Original:
I halved the recipe. It wasn't the BEST cookie I've ever had, but I rated it 5 stars since it held up to last minute changes. I didn't know I was out of vanilla so I substituted almond. My boyfriend liked the flavor, but since I wanted a traditional sugar cookie I wasn't impressed. I ended up being a quarter cup short of granulated sugar so I subbed brown sugar. I was pleased the cookie stood up to the occasion. I decided to make some of the cookies "special" by placing M&Ms on top of the balls. They formed PERFECTLY shaped cookies. I also cut the mini fun sized snicker bars into quarters (NOT the larger fun sized ones) and pushed them into the uncooked cookie balls and then pressed the sides up to reform the ball. They came out EXCELLENT! I also rolled some of the balls in dried coconut powder (really more like minced coconut rather than a fine powder) Those were ALSO delicious. They came out so gorgeous. I'm definitely doing that again. My guests loved them and loved testing the special ones. This is a good standard sugar cookie that I look forward to experimenting with in the future. Recommend adding candies and such for a little bit of fun.

text:
These were really good. I've never baked sugar cookies before (I'm a cake baker) and I followed the exact recipe. They turned out perfectly, a slight crunch at first and then chewy cookie overall - a really nice sugar cookie. I used these to make sugar skull cookies for the Dia de Los Muertos so they held up great with all the decorations. As a frosting base on the cookie before I decorated with icing, I (1) brushed melted butter on top of the cookie and dipped the top of the cookie in a cinnamon and sugar mix, and (2) melted mexican chocolate and put it on top of the cinnamon sugar mix. Once the chocolate was dry I was able to decorate the cookies with royal icing as usual. They were PHENOMENAL!!!! I baked at least 100 cookies and they were gone in mere minutes.

userID:
21235356
Display Name:
Jessica Long
isPro:

followersCount:
4

38
favoritesCount:
41

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4541880.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, the only changes I made was to add the zest of one lemon to the creamed sugar/butter mixture. It adds an extra note of brightness to the cookies. I disagree with other reviewers who said that one teaspoon was too much salt. I think it might depend on how you are frosting the cookies as to whether one tsp is too much salt or not. I've used a chocolate ganache frosting and a vanilla confectioners frosting with colored sugar sprinkles and both of those super sweet frostings balanced out the salt content of the cookie quite perfectly.  I also chill the dough for at least 3 hours before scooping out into balls and then slightly flatten cookies with the bottom of a measuring cup dipped in flour. They bake perfectly every time, 11 minutes.  Let cool on cookie sheet for one minute and then transfer to wire rack to finish cooling.

text:
These cookies are so good! I have made them 3 times already, and have come out great every time!!! I like the addition of rolling them in the sugar before baking them, it really adds a lot of sweetness to the cookie.  The only thing I changed while making this recipe was the shortening. Instead of shortening I substituted the shortening with butter, and it came out just fine, so if you don't have any shortening you can use butter. If you're looking for a quick and simple cookie recipe that doesn't require much skill or a trip to the food store for supplies, this one is it!

text:
Mine were excellent, and I just rolled the tops in chocolate jimmies and  some in coarse clear sugar before baking 10 minutes. They were NOT too salty as one comment suggested, which had me wary of making these. I creamed each step a bit longer than the video and sifted my dry ingredients prior to addition. I chilled the dough while I set out the decorations and in between batches,each batch came out more fluffy. These were both beautiful and delicious.

I doubled the recipe, adding a teaspoon of orange extract.  (I could've added more; I couldn't detect the flavor.) The dough seemed really dry and crumbly, but came together as I formed it into balls.  After the first batch came out of the oven still looking like balls, I flattened them out with my hands before dipping them into sprinkles. That did the trick. They are soft. I really like the simplicity of the recipe with no refrigeration.

text:
I halved the recipe and used just butter bc people reported tasting the shortening and I didn't want to chance it.  I agreed that the cookies tasted buttery and salty, very delicious but not very sweet. I glazed them with buttercream frosting I microwaved for a few seconds, then sprinkled with nonpareils.
One thing I want to point out is that I rolled out the dough to use a cookie cutter and while it was a bit sticky, rolling it out between wax paper and putting it in the freezer for a bit before cutting worked out fine.  I wish I could post a picture, they came out so great I'm making a whole batch today for my niece's first birthday party tomorrow!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A sugar cookie lover all my life, I made these heavenly cookies pretty much exactly to the recipe. The two exceptions are I made each ball a bit larger than a walnut (my yield was 44 cookies rather than 4 1/2 dozen), and flattened each ball to approximately 1/4 to 3/8 inch with a smooth bottom glass before baking for exactly 8 minutes. We've found that the longer these cookies remain in the cookie jar, the more delightfully developed the flavors become. One final note: a reviewer said that there was way too much salt in this recipe. We do not concur. The sweet/salty ratio is perfect in our opinion, and adds yet another dimension to savor. All this cookie ever needs is another glass of milk, please! Kudos to the creator.

text:
This recipe is awesome!  I will definitely make them again.  I followed the ingredients exactly and made snickerdoodles with it.  I did not roll them out though as the dough seemed too soft for that.  Instead, I formed them into balls.  I also chilled the dough for about two hours before forming them into balls to make the dough easier to handle. I baked them for 10 minutes and they turned out so soft and with just a little crispiness on the edges.  Perfecto!  

I saw where one review said that these are like the Lofthouse cookies. I didn't really think so.  Even though I made snickerdoodles with it, I could tell that the consistency isn't really like Lofthouse cookies. Still though, these are very, very good!

Way too much salt!! I would at LEAST half it next time! Also, if you don't want cookie balls, you must press the balls down (I used the underside of a big spoon). Maybe a seasoned sugar maker would know that, but I realized it halfway through! Other than that...delicious!!!!! PERFECT texture...slightly crunchy on the outside with a soft/cake-y inside...mmmmmm....almost makes up for too much salt! lol

These cookies were really good.  I made sure to flatten the cookies out with the bottom of a glass (after rolling and dipping in sugar) as some reviewers said they required this.   They are not the prettiest cookie as they puff up a lot and don't have that flat sugar cookie look, but they are super soft and chewy and the flavour is way better than a traditional sugar cookie.  The recipe made almost 5 dozen, and our family devoured them within 24 hours...need I say more?

text:
These turned out almost absolutely perfect! The ONLY down side was that there was TOO MUCH SALT. Next time half of a teaspoon will be enough. I mixed the sugar crystals with real sugar, and it allowed me to use less crystals and looked fine! Other than that, I just followed the recipe - no modifications.  The biggest tip I can give is this: when you are creaming the butter, shortening, and sugar, MAKE SURE YOU GET IT VERY, VERY FLUFFY! It makes a big difference. This is my new favorite sugar cookie recipe! I love the effect that the shortening AND butter have on the cookies!

text:
This is my favorite sugar cookie recipe.  I've received many compliments on how delicious and perfect they were.  I bake the cookies for only 7 minutes and they come out perfect and chewy.  However, I do find that they are more delicate and break easier.  If you leave them in the oven for 8-9 minutes they will have more color but tend to get harder.  So it's all a matter of preference.   They are delicious either way!

text:
These cookies are wonderful! The key is to not overcook them, pull out of oven before they golden- I bakes for 9 minutes and I used a tiny ice cream scoop for the size of my cookies. I then took a juice glass, dipped the bottom in sugar, and then pressed the cookie down slightly. I do think that 1 tsp is a tad too much salt, but like with everything else, that is based on my personal tastes.

text:
Where have these cookies been all my life??? I have searched forever to find a soft, bakery style sugar cookie, trying several recipes, and always disappointed with the outcome.  Not with this one. I followed the recipe as written, other than adding a bit more flour, and instead of rolling the dough in the sugar, I frosted them after baking with a cream cheese frosting.  These are FABULOUS!

Tip - watch the cookies closely.  You want to take them out of the oven just before they look completely done.  Let them cool on the cookie sheet completely.  They will stay soft for several days.

text:
In my opinion, this is the perfect sugar cookie: Puffy without being cakey, soft without being doughy, sweet but not sickly sweet. Actually they taste to me like smaller versions of those big unfrosted sugar cookies you get from Subway. I followed the recipe exactly except that instead of rolling them in sugar, I left them plain and plan to frost them for a Halloween party (though I'm only doing this to make them look cute, flavor-wise I don't think they need it!). I also used butter-flavor shortening. Sometimes I prefer a more delicate sugar cookie, but whenever I want a tasty, sturdy, basic one, this will be my go-to recipe from now on!

text:
Not bad and nothing spectacular. Just your typical tried-and-true sugar cookie recipe. They didn't bake out the way I would have preferred- thin and flat. They were great straight from the oven (what cookie isn't?!). The bottoms were slightly crisp while the rest of the cookie melted with each bite. I always underbake my cookies, but this recipe did call for the perfect baking time. Ten minutes was all I needed. I was craving sugar cookies and these hit the spot.

text:
These didn't turn out exactly as I thought they would (I was originally looking for a recipe for more cake-like cookies similar to the frosted ones sold at Kroger's bakery)... This recipe caught my interest though, so decided to give it a shot. Delicious! And I like the way the cookies can be thoroughly baked without having to turn the slightest bit brown, even on the bottom. 

I hand creamed the fats/sugar, and palm-rolled dough into small walnut-sized balls as called for in the recipe, but ended up with 3 dozen. Maybe rolled out and cut with cookie cutters would yield closer to 4 1/2 dozen, but unless I made a mistake somewhere I can't see getting 4 1/2 dozen out of this recipe.

Overall- easy, tasty, and had lots of fun making and decorating w/sprinkles with my 9-year-old son!

text:
Very simple and tasty cookies.   The cookie has a nice flavor..not too sweet.   The cookie has a soft bite to it with a more crisp outside.  Only bake for the 12 minutes.   Cookies will be softer if you take off pan right away to cool on wire rack.  I was looking for an easy and tasty cookie to bring to my daughters school party and didn't want to deal with cutouts.   These are perfect!   Perfect with butter icing recipe on this site.

text:
UPDATE 2: SENT MY FIANCE TO WORK W/ LEFTOVERS FRI. EVERYONE LOVED THEM (AND PASSED COMPLIMENTS TO HIM TO PASS ON TO ME!). UPDATE: THESE ROCK!!! REMINDS ME OF THE LOFTHOUSE COOKIES SOLD AT THE GROCERY STORE (AND THEY ODDLY TASTE SWEETER THAN I REM DAYS AGO). OH, AND THEY ARE STILL SUPER SOFT!!! These are pretty good. I prefer sweeter cookies, but for how easy these are to make, I am happy w/ the outcoome. I'm a sucker for Cheryl & Co.'s sugar cookies, & was hoping for a cookie similar to theirs (you know, those pre-wrapped cookies that come in the mail at Cmas...), but these didn't quite hit the mark.... One thing to note: If you do not store your cookies soon after pulling them out of the oven (I used my air-tight Tupperware container), they will bcome crumbly. Be mindful of that. I followed Laura's direct. to the ltr. w/ the except. of 1 step. Aft. seeing that these bake high & pouffy (they do not spread at all), I decided to slightly flatten my next 3 batches - yes, I got DOUBLE the amt. of cookies sugg. (I even rolled into walnut sze. balls as direct., using my sm. PC scoop for uniform.)!!!! I ended up dipping 1/2 of my cookies in red decorator's sugar (b4 baking) & baked the other 1/2 plain & then frosted w/ pink tinted vanilla frosting (from the can) & sprinkled w/ red sugar. My cookies baked up perfectly in 12 min., but watch carefully after 8-10 min. as everyone's oven temps vary. All in all, these were a nice add. to my V Day cookie tray. T you for sharing! :-)

text:
The best sugar cookie recipe EVER!   These turned out perfect!  Nice and soft not overly sweet so you can enjoy with icing.  We think they are better than the Lofthouse Cookies!  Followed the recipe exactly and had no problem rolling them out and using cookie cutters.  With the left over dough I rolled them in a ball and then flattened the ball some with my palm efore baking, as I just didn't think the would "melt" into a flat cookie as the cookies pretty much stayed in the original shape except they puffed up a bit.   New favorite recipe and big hit with family and friends!

text:
The texture and flavor of these are wonderful! I followed the recipe to a"t" and they came out perfect!  I coated half in granulated sugar, but the rest I left plain to add a dollop of frosting and a cherry :) Both were great!  I did keep the dough in the fridge between batches though. Not sure if it made much of a difference but just wanted to make sure they stayed a good consistency.  Make sure you do cream the soft ingredients very well  until fluffy (just with a spoon though) and DO take them out at 10 mins. They may look a smidgen undercooked, but by the time they cool for a few minutes on the pan and you transfer them to rack they stay perfect (even the next day)!

The perfect sugar cookie- point blank and simple. The only change I made was putting the dough into the fridge for an hour to chill for easier rolling later on. I topped the cookies with a cream cheese icing (2 tablespoons cream cheese, 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, 1/4 tsp almond extract, and 1 1/2 cup of powdered sugar over a double broiler) and sprinkles.

text:
I used the butter flavored shortening for more flavor, as someone else suggested.  They "tasted" good, but weren't "soft" or "chewy" as I'd hoped.  Someone else said they reminded them of a buscuit consistency, which is exactly what they reminded me of.  I followed everything to a "T" but for some reason the cookies didn't flatten out.  They more or less stayed pretty close to their initial "ball shape" that we rolled them into.  I tried rolling them into balls with the dough at room temperature as well as refrigerated.  Same result either way.  Tried helping them along by flattening them with a fork.  Still didn't spread out, and stayed the way I flattened them.  I've seen other recipes that don't call for shortening, so I'm wondering if maybe that had something to do with the results??

Best Sugar cookie recipe I've made yet! Still soft and chewy the next day and it was easy enough to alter for a nice variation of cookies. :) I ended up dipping some in melted chocolate(I recommend Dolchi Frutta chocolate dots. Each was absolutely delicious! The boyfriend had at least seven in one sitting, so it passes the test ;)  I'll be making this again for parties and holiday occasions.

Ok, I am a sugar cookie NUT, and I love this recipe.  I put them in a bag after cooling and frosted them the next day. The cookies are perfect after letting them sit.  I ate them after cooling and wasn't impressed; however, they were AMAZING the next day. You won't be disappointed with this cookie, I promise!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were outstanding!  The texture and flavor were really good.  Since I was being lazy and didn't want to measure out both the butter and shortening, I used 1 c (3/3 as opposed to 2/3) and lowered the amount of shortening to 1/3 cup.  They turned out fine.  Since these don't spread, be sure to use the back of a measuring cup to smash them down.  We made 3 different batches, one with just plain sugar, one with the cinnamon sugar mixture and the last set using "Sugar Cookie Icing" from this site.  All were amazing.  I do suggest if you use the cinnamon sugar mixture, to roll them in it while it is a ball, then flatten it on the cookie sheet and then sprinkle some more cinnamon sugar on it.  I highly recommend this to everyone!

text:
I made this recipe gluten free by substituting gluten-free flour where it called for regular and it turned out amazing!  I will definitely be using this recipe again, the kids LOVED it!!  The gluten free flour mix I use is: 2 cups rice flour; 2/3 cup potato starch; 1/3 cup tapioca flour; 1 tsp xantham gum.  Thanks!!

text:
Amazing! My toddlers were bored this afternoon, so we decided to make some purple cookies (read as: sugar cookies mixed with red and blue food coloring) and these were a smash hit! PERFECT texture and consistency--crisp around the edges but ultra soft and fluffy on the inside--the ideal sugar cookie. I added a tiny bit more sugar to the recipe after reading they weren't too sweet based off the recipe--just a hint--and they were perfect for our tastes. I also rolled the cookies into balls, rolled said balls in sugar, and flattened them slightly with a drinking glass. When baked between 8-9 minutes, they were perfect. Definitely the best sugar cookie recipe I've ever tried. This one is a keeper! :)

Very similar to Lofthouse cookies, especially with frosting and sprinkles.  My only complaint is that they seemed a tad on the salty side. region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were a soft sugar cookie. The key to great soft texture is to not cook to long. I would suggest not letting them brown. As soon as I saw the slightest and I mean slightest hint of color I took them out and let them cool for at least 2o mins before removing from the pan. I was afraid to under cook them and let the first batch turn golden all around the edges and did not like the crunchy effect. I topped with frosting. 
next time I may add almond extract or lemon extract, flavor is pretty plain.

text:
This is just the recipe I was looking for! I have my faithful cut-out recipe but was looking for a drop one and this is now part of my collection.  I will say to make sure you do not over mix the dry in to the cream mixture. Only mix until the dough comes together. Over mixing will lead to a cookies that will not rise. I also flattened my quite a bit with a bottom of a glass because they do not spread a lot. I just added colored sugar to the tops and got my glass of milk ready!  Thanks!

text:
I had my doubts about these initially, as they just seemed "too good to be true"- drop cookies instead of roll-out, basic ingreedients, simple recipe overall...but these are hands-down the best sugar cookies I've ever made. They're easy *and* they turn out better than any other recipe I've tried, which are usually flat, dense, and plain. These are light, fluffy, and SOFT just like the ones you buy in a bakery. I didn't roll them in sugar, just left them as plain walnut sized balls (I make them pretty large) and frost them in white "whipped" frosting, with a few rainbow sprinkles on top :) Always a favorite! Thanks for this incredible recipe!

text:
I made these cookies today, after looking at many other recipes. They were great because I didn't have to run to the store to get anything. After I mixed it all together, I had enough for 3 cookie sheets. The first batch, the dough was hard to roll in my hand because it was very sticky so I put it in the fridge for batches 2 & 3. That made it a whole lot easier. I sprinkled crystal sprinkles over the top before I baked them. I haven't tried them (gave em up for Lent) but my family is going to try them later. They smell great!

text:
I am giving these 5 stars even though I haven't tasted them.  I have given up sweets for Lent so not a bite has passed my lips.  I followed the recipe exactly as written and the dough was easy to work with and they baked up beautifully!  I sprinkled each cookie with additional sugar after I pulled them out of the oven then allowed them to cool on the sheets for 3 or 4 minutes.  They looked perfect, exactly like the ones I used to eat from bakeries.  My husband is the taster and so he will be the final judge.  My 5-year-old daughter liked them but hers is not the most discerning palate - if it is sweet, she likes it!  I will definitely be making these again.

These cookies have a great flavor. I liked the fact that they don't call for very many ingred. and the ones that it calls for are your eveyday things. I did notice one thing though, and that is that you can't overbake them, not even a little bit because they harden up. So because I decided to do roll cookies from this recipe, I had to watch them very carefully. I used cold butter right from the refrigerator so they rolled out nicely. All and all this is a good recipe. I keeping it!

country:
None
text:
These cookies are GREAT. I dont normally eat sugar cookies. My daughter has made these twice this week. A few tips.. Decrease the salt. You could really taste it in the first batch. Perfect the second time ,with the salt adjustment.
I think the key with these cookies are to roll them out, or make sure they are thick cookies. If you are looking for a soft cookie. Do not OVER BAKE. Let them cool on a WIRE RACK, This is a must have in cookie baking to prevent carry over baking. Which can cause dry hard cookies.
DONT LOOK FOR ANOTHER SUGAR COOKIE RECIPE THIS ONE WONT LET YOU DOWN. 
I used butter flavor shortening and butter, other than that I just decreased the salt. Enjoy!!!!

text:
This is a great recipe. I don't care for crispy hard cookies. So I was excited to find this recipe. One thing I will say is that when I made these I dropped them with a standard size disher (size 20 I think. really just a large melon baller.)and baked them for 10 to 12 minutes like the recipe said but they were not finished. I ended up having to bake them for a total of about 15 minutes. After that they were perfect. I think this recipe's author has an oven that runs hot because mine has a thermometer in it and is accurate so be careful. As for the taste I might add more sugar or an extract or orange zest for added flavor and sweetness. These cookies also don't spread very much so mash them down a bit if you like.

text:
I love these cookies made just as the recipe says.  I do make an addition that has caused my family to request these cookies for every single holiday.  Instead of rolling them in sugar, I bake them without.  I then frost them with a simple almond frosting, then place three M&M's in the frosting.  They are incredibly good like this.  All of the people that said this cookie was too bland should try them with this addition.  A medium sized cookie scoop makes this already simple recipe even easier - it also is the perfect size for 3 M&M's in the frosting.

text:
This was so easy! I've made the recipe twice, once as recipe calls (in balls, and the second time I used my cookie press. This dough works excellent in the press. I've had problems with other doughs being to sticky in it, but this was perfect. It literally took about 5 min to place all dough on my cookie sheets with my cookie press. I then sprinkled sugar on top and baked. I do recommend using an aluminum pan. Turns out super soft and light on the bottoms. Thanks so much!

text:
This cookie isn't bad, but I don't really like the way the flavor of the Crisco comes out so strongly in the cookie.  Perhaps it needs butter flavored Crisco, rather than the original that I used?  They started to harden within 30 minutes of being baked, so they aren't really soft, but they are chewy. Also, I got 45 walnut shaped balls, and the recipe is for 24.  I used red and green sugar and only dipped the tops of the cookies.  I was looking for some new additions to my Christmas cookie line up, but as is, I wouldn't serve them to guests.  I might try these again with some changes to the original recipe.

I wanted to make the cookies harder, so I extended the baking time on a baking stone from 12 to about 18 minutes, and the sugar cookies really firmed up nicely. Turns out Ive been using the wrong sugar cookie my whole life, because these are PERFECT. Typically I browse through the comments for added tips, but not this time. They are literally like the fluffy perfect cookies you pick up at a bakery. I did one batch the size of those tiny little puppy tennis balls, and one batch walnut sized. The only difference was a minute or two in the oven. I started them at 8 minutes and watched them. Theyre so good Im not even frosting them!

None
text:
A simple, basic, truly delicious sugar cookie. I use a small (ice cream type) scoop to portion out the dough, partially flatten them with a cup bottom and sprinkle sugar on the top before baking.  They are done when they just start to brown around the edges. If the dough is refrigerated, it needs to warm to room temp. before scooping.

text:
These are great cookies, and as promised, nice and soft. I suggest refrigerating the dough for a half hour to an hour so the dough is easier to work with when shaping. I used a cookie scoop and rolled the dough into balls and then pressed flat between my palms. Much easier than slicing and my son was able to help! I then used the Sugar Cookie Frosting recipe on here to frost them. With some sprinkles added by my kiddo, these were not only delicious, but a fun activity.

text:
I loved these cookies! Some of them were a little more brown at the bottom, and they were a bit misshapen, BUT they were absolutely delicious! :D They were soft, but chewy. I sprinkled the sugar on top because they were to brittle to roll in it, and it turned out nicely. (I used organic cane sugar.) They had to be put in for longer in my stove, for 4 minutes longer.(So 14-18 minutes instead of 10-12) Overall, I'd say I'd make these again. They also tasted a bit saltier than usual, but I liked it because it contrasted with how lightly sweet they were. :3

Everyone said "11 minutes" and they were right. I even cooked them in a convection oven, so I lowered the temp by 25 degrees (to 325). text:
So far so good, cookies are still cooling.  Even though I halved the salt as suggested by some reviews it was still pronounced.  Next time Ill only use 1/4 tsp.  I ran out of regular flour so I subbed 2 cups of gluten free flour and I used two sticks butter and 1/3 cup coconut oil since I didnt have shortening on hand.  Not sure if thats to blame but the first still warm cookie I tried fell apart, hopefully as they cool they firm up. Otherwise pretty happy with the recipe.  I sprinkled with confetti sugar before baking one batch.  I flattened them a bit before cooking since so many reviews said they did not spread.  Mine did spread.  I put some of the batter in the fridge as the first cooked and cooled.  Ill see if that makes a difference and update my review if it does.

These cookies are AMAZING. I have tried so many different cookie recipes and none of them have been anywhere as good as these. Theyre soft and delicious! I used butter because its what I had, and I baked them only until the centers no longer looked wet. For me, that was about 8-10 minutes. I rolled some of the dough into balls like the recipe said, and I also rolled this dough out and used cookie cutters. Each cookie was perfect! I highly recommend this if you want a chewy, soft, and delicious sugar cookie!!!

text:
I wanted to try out a sugar cookie recipe that I did not have to chill and roll out. I usually add an extra egg to the recipe so I did that and I also added some almond extract. in reading reviews I saw that they tend to maintain their ball-shape, so if you wanted flat cookies you had to press them down with a flat bottom cup, which is what I did. Overall, this is the easiest recipe for sugar cookies I've ever tried. I did try one and it was very good. I still I'm cooking the rest of the batches so I do not know if the cookies will remain as soft as they are Fresh Out the Oven, but right now they are perfect
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-12-23T11:48:04.14
helpfulCount:

text:
Amazing sugar cookies!   Easy to mix and after rolling into balls I pressed with the bottom of a fancy cup to imprint a pattern.  Came out perfect!  The only change I made is I melted the shortening first and than let it cool.  I do this with all cookies as it helps make them soft and it mixes in better with the dough.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe as written. I did make sure to cream the butter and sugar until they were very light and fluffy. I did not chill the dough and baked it immediately. I used a tablespoon to measure out the dough and rolled it into balls and then rolled the edges in sprinkles. I used the bottom of a glass to very lightly flatten the dough balls. These cookies did not spread a lot and ended up being very soft and chewy with a slightly crisp edge. Do not overbake,they will set up on the cookie sheet when removed from the oven. Their flavor is subtle but pairs well with a sweet frosting. I would definitely use this recipe again.

text:
Have made these twice. It's an easy recipe, the cookies make your house smell heavenly, and these are hands down the BEST sugar cookies I've ever tasted. Not too sweet, doesn't crumble as you eat it,  stays fresh at least 3 days, that's how long they lasted before disappearing.  I've done a half recipe and full, the half made 26 cookies, the full produced 60. 
 I iced some so I could try out icing recipes and they hold the icing or frosting very nicely without it adding moisture to the cookie.  Very, very pleased.

country:
None
text:
i didn't have hard shortening such as "Crisco", so i used safflower oil which is a light oil like sunflower oil. That was my only substitution (other than rolling the cookie dough in colored sugars prior to baking to give them some omph!  for the grandkids.)  That said, the cookies were very fluffy & soft. The colored sugar crystals melted some while baking so the melted sugar encased them in their own packaging keeping them soft until they were  all eaten. Do not  over bake.

text:
Cookies were perfect, quick tip...use a small ice cream scoop (the squeeze and release kind) and drop by the tablespoon on a cookie sheet lined with a non stick sheet. Dip a glass in sugar and gently smashed the cookie until desired thickness was achieved. Perfect, round, delectable, soft, sugar cookies. Happy kids = happy mom!

None
text:
These cookies are sweet and soft. I ran out of vanilla so I used one tsp of vanilla and one tsp of almond extract. You can refrigerate the dough before baking but since I was only going to roll into balls I didn't but because the dough is so soft; it must be refrigerated at least a day of rolling out. These cookies do not spread whatsoever; therefore, you must press with the bottom of a glass to desired shape. I do believe this resize will work great in a cookie press.

text:
2-3-2017  ~For me this was at best an average cookie, sugar cookie or other.  I guess if you like cakey, soft, thick cookies youd disagree with me but in my view, were it not for the buttercream frosting I covered them with, this would not be the cookie Id grab seconds for.  Hubs is one of those I mentioned above and disagrees with me, however, he did say it was the total package; that he would not have liked these without the frosting.  Note:  I flattened these slightly before popping them into the oven and Im glad I did  they would have been little poof balls had I not.  Also, I know I would have liked these much better baked longer but then these would be more chewy, even crispy, and not the soft cookies these are meant to be.

text:
After reading all the rave reviews, I guess I'm the only person on the planet who didn't like this recipe.... sorry !   One reviewer said she'd used all butter instead of half shortening/half butter.
I don't like to bake with anything but butter so I tried it that way.  Mine turned out VERY hard/crisp, like little hockey pucks.  So then I made it the way called for.....  at least they were softer,
but taste-wise lacked that wonderful buttery taste... more of just a so-so taste.   Third batch I went back to my Mom's old, old
recipe.....soft, wonderful, all-butter...the recipe has never failed me.  However they are roll-out cookies, granted kind of a pain !

I followed the recipe exactly as stated. I did chill for about an hour so I could roll out . I sprinkled powdered sugar  on parchment paper  & rolled dough out and they came out perfectly. I only baked for about 9 minutes otherwise they would have been too hard (just  depends on your oven) My only complaint was the cookies were too salty. Next time I will use only a 1/2 tsp.salt or unsalted butter. Topped with homemade buttercream frosting & they were a big hit. Will definitely make these cookies again.

text:
A little too flavorless.  I remade these with half again as much vanilla  (3tsp) and used butter flavored shortening.  Also used unsalted butter.  They were delicious the 2nd time around.  Try these amendments - you won't be sad.  Also found the balls did need to be flattened before cooking.  They cook more evenly that way.  These don't spread much at all so don't be afraid to put them pretty close together on the pan.

Display Name:
Parker

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5783168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been searching for a good sugar cookie recipe for a while. The flavour is fantastic. But I didn't roll them out into balls because of other reviewer's suggestions. Instead I rolled out the dough with a rolling pin to be about one quarter of an inch thick. Then I used a round 2 1/2 inch cookie cutter to cut out my cookies. And I dipped the top of the cookies with sugar.  I left the cookies in for 15 minutes.  This produced a crunchy, only slightly chewy cookie which is exactly what I wanted. This method of portioning resulted in approximately twice as many cookies than the recipe indicates.  With these adjustments I will be making these cookies again on a regular basis.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Fantastic cookie recipe. I was hesitant to use it, as I'm a "butter all the way!!!" Type person. I've made other cookies with shortening before, and I thought they were okay. but a butter recipe won my heart in the end. So I approached this recipe with trepidation. But since I had shortenin on hand, I had nothing to lose. I am so glad I gave it a try. I made a full recipe for my son to take to his class, and then my husband took the rest to coworkers. Both the class and coworkers agreed this cookie was a perfect/amazing/wonderful sugar cookie. I now have two sugar cookie recipes in my recipe index. (The other is thinner/crunchier cookie). I suppose I will have to restock on some shortening before the holidays. Nonetheless, let it be stated, butter makes everything better and always will. The half and half is a great way to increase the soft/chewiness and get a butter flavor.  Thus making them such a hit.

text:
I followed the dough recipe exactly as instructed but made a few changes during baking. After I rolled them into balls, I pressed them down into the pan and I'm glad I did. They really don't flatten or grow very much, so they came out exactly the size and shape I wanted, although I did come out with about 36 cookies. I skipped dipping them in sugar because I knew I wanted to frost them, and they're wonderful frosted. They aren't crunchy, but slightly crispy on the bottom and the perfect amount of chewiness throughout the cookie. Will definitely make again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these a few times for holiday parties and BBQ's.  They are always a big hit and by the end of the party all that's left is crumbs. I love how soft and chewy they are without that undercooked taste you sometimes get with "moist" cookies. I followed the recipe exactly as it is and used a simple sugar cookie frosting I found on here.  I think if I had one small complaint it is that they don't spread out at all.  After rolling them into a ball, I use the bottom of a glass that's buttered and covered in sugar to press them into 1/2" disks.  It's no big deal, just makes for a little more work.

text:
I was very pleased with this recipe. I didn't have any shortening on hand, so I used all butter. I also added about 1/2 cup more flour than the recipe called for , which made the dough less sticky for handling and rolling into balls.  These alterations didn't adversely affect either the flavour or the texture. The cookies held their shape beautifully, baked up soft, and tasted delicious.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/33699.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I normally follow recipes completely as is.  Due to laziness, snow and my desire not to go to the store when I made these I 1) used butter instead of shortening  2) only used about 1/2 teaspoon salt 3) did not mix by hand but used mixer on low speed and 4) flattened them after they had sugar put on them and before they went into the oven.  It's a preference, if you don't, they will come out more  like half a  circle and thicker in the middle.   They tasted delicious, they are not a chewy cookie, but nor are they "break your teeth crunchy."  They aren't crumbly either.  I look forward to frosting the next batch.  They were a big hit with our office staff.  Thank you for sharing the recipe!  It's a keeper for me!

userID:
17462575
Display Name:
JBR

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe as written, except I used probably only 3/4 t. of salt, which I think was a good thing.  I live at 7,000 ft.  but made no adjustments, using 350 degrees F with a convection/bake setting.  However, I took my dough and made two long log rolls, probably 2" in diameter, and wrapped in plastic wrap.  I think refridgerated them for about 2 hours, taking them out of the fridge 10 min. before slicing.  I made the slices about 1/3-1/2 inch wide with a very sharp knife, and then placed them on the baking sheets.  They weren't quite perfectly round due to the flat bottom, so I used my fingers once they were on the sheet to "round" each on e a bit more.  They baked 10 minutes, until the edges were just slightly brown.  I had absolutely NO problems doing the cookies this way, and it saved me quite a bit of time.  I frosted them with buttercream frosting and sprinkles.   For Valentine's Day, I may try using heart cookie cutters.

I make BIG birthday cookies for all my kids and grands but I don't want to make a big batch of cookie dough because i'll eat what I don't send!   I used butter instead of a mix of shortening and butter 1/2&1/2. Instead of whipping up an egg and using 1/2 of it, I just used a whole egg.  I needed to increase the bake time 2 minutes because I made 3 big cookies instead of 6 normal ones. SO YUMMY! My girls will love them, the 3rd one was for me of course, had to make sure they were good right?!

text:
YUM, YUM, YUM! These are so delicious! I don't even really LIKE sugar cookies, but I just ate three of these straight out of the oven.  I wanted something cute to make for my  Dental Assisting class, so I bought a tooth and toothpaste cookie cutter and they came out super adorable and really held their shape!  I didn't have any problems with them falling apart, and the cookie remains just the perfect crisp to moist ratio. I left them in 10 minutes and it was perfect. Any longer and I think they would have overcooked. Cannot wait to ice these tomorrow and will be making again!

I've shied away from sugar cookies before because they never turn out for me. These are amazing! I did a test sheet with some  dropped, some pressed with fingers and some pressed with a glass on one sheet taking a few out at different intervals of time. I could not tell the difference between the finger pressed and glass pressed as they all raised a bit. I pressed a few of the dropped cookies after baking and they look good too. I had my 19yr old son test the done-ness. He liked the flattened ones I took out at 10 min. best until I gave him the drop cookie that I took out at 12 min. Delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Make cookies a day ahead- they taste better  also Better with this frosting - this frosting will set a bit but tays on the soft side - just leave space around edge & don't stack cookies. better next day
frosting recipe- you will have left over or make a 1.5 recipe
3 cup powdered sugar
1/4 tsp salt
1/4 cup milk
1/3 c soft butter
3 TBL sour cream
1 tsp vanilla
milx & put a spoon full on top in middle of cookie- stays pretty wet until next day so leave room on sides & don't stack cookies

you can add lemon zest , lemon juice & or extract- I get the crystalized lemon & add it in to dough & juice & extract to frosting for lemony flavor
peppermint extract to dough & frosting , top with a peppermint Hershey kiss for holiday or pink, red & white andes mints, or white peppermint hershy's kisses chopped , or frosting recpe above add peppermint extract & top with chopped candy cane pieces

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love store-bought sugar cookies because they are super soft and frosted and wonderful. So I decided to make these so I wouldn't need to buy them.They did NOT come out as expected. The dough wouldn't fan out on the sheet while cooking, it just stayed in a ball so I had to squish them into a cookie shape before baking them. When they came out and cooled, they felt hard as rocks on the outside and kind of looked like snickerdoodles. On the inside, they were not even done (and they had been given extra cooking time). My brother tried them, and gave them a 5/10. The only things in the recipe I changed was I used half as much salt and added a bit of water since the dough wouldn't come together. Maybe this recipe is for more experienced bakers, but I don't think I'll be making them again any time soon.

Delicious and easy to make. I agree that 1tsp of salt is too much. Like the other reviewer, I should have trusted my instincts and left out the salt. But my kids don't think they're salty. Oh, and I only used butter, no shortening and replaced 3/4 cup of the regular flour with coconut flour. I find the coconut flour is great for high altitude baking living in Denver. Try it out without the salt.

Just finished baking these. I really like the dough, easy to work with and they shape and bake beautifully. My only issue is that IMO they have a slight raw flour taste. I'm betting these cookies will be better eaten the next day; we will see.
