text:
I chose this recipe last night since I needed 5 dozen cookies for my son's school this morning. They requested soft sugar cookies so this is the recipe I chose. I followed this recipe to a T but my cookies never flattened out!
I had to flatten them with a spatula once they were in the oven for a few minutes and they still were not a *soft* cookie. They were hard on the outside and semisoft on the inside :(
The taste was great, so on that note I tried the recipe again stayed up late and finished them but again, I had to flatten them myself.
Any advice/opinions/suggestions would be appreciated as I would love to be able to make a soft sugar cookie ;)

me, my husband and our grandson did a joint effort in making these today. I did have to add time as 10-12 minutes left them doughy.

None
text:
I made these cookies for a party and they were a hit. I've had at least a half a dozen people come up to me and ask for the recipe. My oven completely shut off and broke, making me use our toaster oven. I found that when put into the toaster oven the cookies rise more and seem to be more dense. If that is the way you like your cookies, then I would actually put them into the toaster oven at 350 degrees for a couple minutes over the time mentioned in the recipe. Make sure to shift the cookies once in a while.

region:

country:
None
text:
I love sugar cookies, but I don't love having to roll out the dough, chill, etc. so this drop cookie recipe was great. I used Mexican vanilla, and that gave them a really nice flavor. I sprinkled them with red and pink sugar for Valentine's Day and the two colors together made them really pretty. I prefer to flatten the balls with a glass and then sprinkle the sugar on; if you don't flatten them they come out very dome shaped and a little irregular looking, but they still taste great. We'll definitely make these again. Ours were done right at 11 minutes. Next time I might try subbing almond extract for the vanilla; I think we would love that too. The soft texture of these cookies is what makes them so good!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This being my first attempt at sugar cookies, which admittedly are the last I reach for in anyone else's house, I did not have high hopes.  I liked the idea of soft cookies and read the first 10 pages of reviews.  Here are the changes I made:  Added 1/2 teaspoon of almond extract, 2 teaspoons cinnamon, 3/4 cup brown sugar and 3/4 white, no salt.  I was making them a full day ahead of time so I didn't even wait for them to get brown on the bottoms before I took them out.  About 8 to 10 min per batch.  I was using a snowflake cookie cutter and quickly learned to keep the dough for those very thick - 1/2 inch - and have lots of flour on my working surface.  I made fork impressions and sprinkled colored sugar on them.  It was a nice alternative to the other gooey/rich desserts I made for Christmas.  And also very good to have with tea, even 2 days post-baking, they are still soft and yummy.

text:
I have to say that these cookies were a huge hit. I used crisco butter flavored shortening sticks, not sure if that changed anything. We put frosting and mini M&M's on them. They are crunchy and chewy. So good!

userID:
5519413
Display Name:
Autum S. Burkett
isPro:
False

5

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6399957.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies came out absolutely fluffy. I used a cookie scoop which made them the perfect size. For the first batch I left them in the rounded shape and it made them SO soft; they were like miniature pillows! For the second batch I used the "peanutbutter cookie fork smoosh" method, but didn't make them too flat. These were the cookies I frosted. They were equally as soft, so it's really personal preference.

For an added touch, on the rounded ones I put a dab of frosting and a single peanutbutter chip. It was mostly a decorative addition. For the flatter ones I frosted them with frosting I'd colored, and sprinkled miniature Tollhouse chocolate chips on it. Since they were semi-sweet it cut down on the sweetness a tiny bit and gave them a little bit of an edge.

Oh, I almost forgot to mention... I added a dash of cinnamon to the recipe and it really gave it just the perfect hint of flavor. :)

country:
None
text:
I made some changes to the origninal recipe, and they are hands down the best cookies Ive ever eaten.

Instead of 2/3 shortening and 2/3 butter, I made it 1 1/3 cup of butter.

I also changed the 2tsp of vanilla to 1tsp of vanilla and 1tsp of almond extract which gives the cookies a wonderful taste! 

Also, because I used salted butter, I only put a pinch of actual salt into the dough.

I found that they only needed to be baked for 9 minuets and they stay soft and chewy! 

Everyone in my family loves them, even the ones who don't even like sugar cookies! 

Ive made them a few times now and will for sure, keep making them!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not much of a fan of sugar cookies because they are too time consuming, too hard and often dry.  These cookies are soft and easy to make.  I followed the recipe exactly except used half the salt because my butter was salted.  I used a small dough scooper so all the cookies would be the same size.  I then rolled them, dipped one side in colored sugar, and flattened them slightly on the pan with a glass.  I baked them for 11 min. and they were hardly brown at all.  I was worried that they might not be done, but trusted my judgement and they were.  Do not go by color to determine if they are done.  The recipe made exactly 4 dozen with my scooper.  There is a lot of butter/shortening in this recipe and that can be tasted in the end result as others have said.  I may try to up the sugar a tad next time.  If you frost these, then don't worry.  The frosting will add the extra sweetness.  These will still remain my go to recipe when I need a sugar cookie fast.

This is by and far the best sugar cookie recipe I have ever made. My mom and I have probably tried a different sugar cookie recipe every holiday season and now my search is over. I used it for rolled out pumpkins for halloween and will be making turkey cutouts with this recipe tomorrow. I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out great. This is a good sugar cookie. I followed the recipe exactly except I flattened the cookie dough balls a little with the bottom of a jar. Good that I did as they did not spread at all. That is actually a good thing as you can see what size cookie you will end up with and can put them closer together on the cookie sheet and save space. 
They tasted good and would stand up to icing too if you wanted to ice them.

text:
This is such a versatile recipe! I've made regular sugar cookies with it and they were awesome, then I tweaked it with ginger, cardamon, cinnamon and orange extract for something a little different, and replaced some of the flour with cocoa powder for decadent chocolate sugar cookies. All turned out great! The original recipe cookies are best when you take them out of the oven when the very edges are just barely staring to brown. They should still look very white on top. I like to decorate them by dipping them or piping on melted Candy Melts. It seems to hold up better than frosting and tastes SO YUMMY!

text:
If you use butter Crisco shortening, make sure you don't add the salt.  Gag! I didn't think about the salt content in the Crisco...  Even without Crisco the 1 tsp still seems like a lot of salt.  That aside it is an ok sugar cookie recipe if you like a soft fluffy inside.  My 4 star rating is based on the overall recipe without the salt oops on my end.  They don't flatten out like you would think so I'd flatten them ahead of time if you don't care for puffy cookies.

country:
None
text:
Simple and delicious!  I made some into Snickerdoodles by rolling them in cinnamon and sugar.  I LOVE chewy cookies, and these are the perfect texture.  The butter mixture looked kinda weird and curdled after I added the vanilla extract, but it didn't seem to affect the chemistry or the flavor.  Also, I had never baked cookies by just putting golf-ball-sized spheres on the pan rather than shaping them in some way, but it works perfectly!  They turned into perfect, golden, cookie-shaped rounds which practically hovered above the parchment paper.  (I didn't believe you could really put them on an unprepared pan, but I was wrong, it seems.)  I did have to cook them a lot longer (maybe 24 minutes or so!) but I think that's 'cause I'd just made custard in a water bath, so there was a LOT of moisture in the oven.  Anyway, thanks for the recipe - it's great!!

Amazing! I made these for my dad today and wrote "HAPPY FATHER'S DAY" in blue icing across 15 cookies... my dad (who has heart disease) loved it so much and could actually enjoy it without having to worry about feeling pain later. 
I cut down the sugar by just a little (1 1/3 cups instead of 1 1/2 cups), and because I didn't have any shortening I used canola oil... still amazing. The dough takes about five minutes to make, the cookies about 15 to bake each batch and I had everything baked and my kitchen cleaned within a half hour. Amazing amazing amazing, will do again.

text:
These were really good and fast to make! I had to make some substitutions because I was out of some things. I used all canola margarine for the butter and shortening, I used half white sugar and half icing sugar, out of vanilla so I used 1 pouch vanilla sugar and rolled the balls in white/clear coarse sugar.Used my tbsp scoop and got 55 cookies, 12 minutes on silpat lined baking sheets was perfect for my oven. Next time I will try my 1/2 tbsp scoop and coloured sugar like the picture.
1/2 tbsp scoop bakes in 7 minutes.
Using my #50 scoop it made 24 large cookies that I rolled in coarse sugar and baked for 18 minutes, I like to use all butter now and omitted the salt, since it was salted.

text:
Today was my first time making these cookies to roll out for valentine day cookie cutters.  I think i rolled to thin the ones that were approx 1/4 inch thick stayed soft. so that i will make sure to keep on the thicker side next time.  Also I cooked until bottom gold brown- they were soft when they came out of the oven but became hard within fifteen minutes so next time I'll plan to take them out even if i think it's too early.  overall though pretty good easy to roll out and they kept there shape and are smooth on top so should frost well with royal icing.  We'll see how it goes with my changes next time.

I only had margarine so I used 1 and 1/3 cup of margarine instead of the butter and shortening. I also beat the egg butter sugar vanilla mixture for a little while until fluffy. We frosted them and they were delish!

text:
I added a 1/4 tsp each of orange and lemon peel and substituted butter for the shortening. These are the perfect cookie to make with young kids. I rolled each piece of cookie dough into a ball and then gave them to my sons to dip into small bowls of sugar and sprinkles. My older son loved being the one who got to mash the balls of dough down with a juice glass before they went in the oven. They had a blast and it was so easy (no rolling out of the dough) that I was able to enjoy it. No stress! Easy clean up. Took 11 minutes at 350, and they were soft and yummy. My husband says these are like the ones his grandmother used to make.

This is the first time I've made cookies from scratch.  They came out delicious.  My husband thought they weren't sweet enough so we added 1/4 cup of sugar the 2nd time around. Display Name:
JAMIEH1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Exactly what I was looking for! I ended up having to make a dessert for a party on short notice, and these were PERFECT! I did decrease salt to 1/2 tsp, and I sifted the flour, salt, and baking powder before adding to creamed ingredients.  In general, use high quality vanilla and real, unsalted butter, and make sure nothing is expired, and your baked goods will turn out better.  If you don't have an essential ingredient (i.e., EGGS!) then DON'T TRY THE RECIPE!  Also, I wonder if the people who gave the bad reviews really understood what "creaming" means.  You need to do it until everything is creamy white and fluffy, or the cookies won't turn out.  I rolled them into larger balls and flattened slightly when dipping them into the colored sugar.  Cooked for 11 minutes and they were great.  I didn't have a single cookie left, and d/h was mad that I didn't make a double batch!

text:
These are soft but not chewy.  I substituted one teaspoon of orange flavoring for one of the teaspoons of vanilla. It gave them a wonderful summer zest.  I made these as favors for a wedding and received many compliments on the flavor.  I used an ice cream scoop to drop them on the cookie sheet (5 to a sheet), flattened them with a glass plate coated in colored sugar and baked them as directed for 11 minutes.

Display Name:
SaltyMama

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you like a soft cake-like cookie as I do, this is the one for you. And if you're also like me in that you hate rolling dough, you'll like them twice as much!  Definitely want to chill the dough before working with it. I just made them for the first time, and made 24 as the recipe suggests and they were huge and it was a bit difficult to get them baked in the center!  Next time I think I'll make 30 cookies.  I took one readers suggestion and rolled some of them in cinnamon/sugar and the rest in plain granulated sugar.  Of course, the sky's the limit there; they'd be wonderful with colored sugars for the holidays and, as some other readers did, they can be frosted as well.  I'm thinking too that I might try adding some cocoa to the dry ingredients (perhaps 1/2 C.  to make them a chocolate cookie. Has anybody else done that?  If so, how did that turn out?

text:
I used all butter and no shortening (I like the butter flavor better!) and made sure it was softened before making the batter.  I made these about a tablespoon each and ended up with almost 50 cookies.  I rolled each cookie in the crystal multi-colored sugar and slightly pressed each with the bottom of a glass.  Because they were smaller I took them out after about 8 minutes and 30 seconds and they were perfect.  These cookies came out beautifully and were delicious.  A big hit in my 3rd grade class Easter party!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/251070.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were great! The shortening is really key.  I left them in for about ten minutes - enough for the outside to be slightly crunchy but the inside to be super moist, even throughout the next few days.  I tried flattening them and using my cookie cutters for one of the batches, but this recipe and it's softness does really work best when it's rolled into balls. The cut-out cookies were good too, though!  Please everyone, don't overcook these! I saw a review of someone mentioning that they were so hard/inedible, so keep them in a few minutes less if you need to! I imagine it's hard to screw these up otherwise.

These cookies were great! They had a realy great flavor.  However, my reasons for giving them 4 stars are A. text:
Super easy! Super yummy! Soft and tasty cookies. I made half this recipe to try it out. I didn't soften the butter, but creamed it while still firm. The dough was a bit sticky, but a small amount of added flour as I rolled did wonders and didn't make them dry. I added a bit of orange zest, as I had some in season from my mom's trees, and WOW! It added a fantastic little flavor. They didn't spread much, bit did pillow a bit if cut thickly. I am going to try frosting these later, but this batch is so good, we may finish them before they cool ^_^

This could use more flavor to it - I reduced the flour and added more sugar. I also added more vanilla and some orange extract. You have to press the balls of dough down - they will not flatten on their own as they bake. I frosted them once they cooled with homemade frosting (shortening, powdered sugar, vanilla extract) and sprinkled cotton candy flavored sugar over it. The cookies were nice and soft and didn't last very long!

I made these according to the recipe, but I did not roll the balls in sugar and I did not flatten them. I did refrigerate the dough for a bit, as my kitchen was warm. They are especially yummy when topped with a few chocolate chips and heated in the microwave 10 - 20 seconds. Scrumptious!

text:
Wow, so good.  I don't bake...ever, but the snow was falling (in march :() and I got the urge to, um, bake.  These were so good!  I wanted a recipe I didn't have to chill or roll, and this fit the bill!  These come out of the oven looking the same as they go in, so make them the size you want them.  I baked for exactly 10 minutes and they didn't look done, they were white on the top, but the bottoms were browned and perfect, so don't bake too long!  Topped with 'butter frosting for sugar cookies' from this website, excellent!  Only change to this recipe, added almond extract instead of vanilla and some lemon juice.  MMMM thanks :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh MAN these were good! Was the 3rd sugar cookie recipe I'd tried in 2 days and even though I couldn't make cut-outs with this, they TASTED AWESOME. Best cookie I've tasted all year hands down, w/ or w/o frosting, no wonder it was a winner. Used a 2" cookie scoop (produced a 3" cookie), baked for 12-15 min. Little crispy outer edges at 15 min. but still SOFT in the middle, puffed up a little in center. Flattened next pan slightly w/ glass to make a more even cookie and baked for 12 m. let set few min. on pan, still slightly crispy edge/soft center but looked better (because of the flattening). 3rd pan baked 11 min. let sit couple min. still slightly crispy etc. so prob. more like 10 min. I also chilled the dough overnight.

text:
This recipe makes great, soft cookies.  The only thing i would add to the instructions is to press down and flatten the dough a bit after you roll them into balls, because they don't spread out much at all in the oven.  The bottom of a glass, or the palm of your hand get the job done.

text:
This cookie is best served at room temperature with a big o' glass of milk. 
The recipe was a little vague. I found that it was best to flat the ball of cookie dough with the sugared bottom of a glass before baking so that the middle got completely done.
Over all it was a wonderful cookie. No wonder it won a Blue Ribbon!
